Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Morphological and developmental disparity dynamics associated with the emergence of commensalism and the loss of swimming in "swimming" crabs
Award.AbstractNarration:
The proposed project will investigate how morphological and developmental diversity accumulated in a unique and charismatic lineage of crabs belonging to the economically important "swimming crab" family Portunidae. Diversification of these crabs included significant ecological divergence that involved abandoning a swimming lifestyle for sedentary, symbiotic relationships with reef-associated organisms. Research will include comparative analyses of size, shape and growth data. The primary goal of this work will be to infer whether significant developmental differences between these crabs were generated before, during or after significant changes in adult forms and whether these divergences correlate to the emergence of symbiotic associations in the group. Results of this work will contribute to an active area of research concerned with how external (e.g. ecological) and internal (e.g. developmental) factors influence morphological diversification.

This project will provide the co-PI with opportunities to foster collaborations both nationally and internationally. It will also facilitate the training of undergraduate students on research methods in molecular systematics. Fieldwork activities will be shared with the public through the science blog "Adventures in Spineless Science!". Specimens, tissue samples and photographs collected for this work will be curated and archived at the Florida Museum of Natural History; making them available for other researchers. Results will be professionally communicated at scientific meetings and through publication in open-access journals.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project investigated the morphological diversity of a lineage of crabs belonging to the economically important "swimming crab" family Portunidae. Diversification of these crabs included significant ecological divergence that involved abandoning a swimming lifestyle for sedentary, symbiotic relationships with reef-associated organisms (soft coral, algae, echinoderms, etc.). Research included phylogenetic comparative analyses of size, shape and growth. The primary goal of this work was to infer whether significant differences in growth patterns between these crabs were generated before, during or after significant changes in adult forms and whether these divergences correlate with the emergence of symbiotic associations in the group. Results of this work contribute to an active area of research concerned with how external (e.g. ecological) and internal (e.g. developmental) factors influence morphological diversification. This project resulted in the development of significant molecular and morphological data for investigating this topic. The project provided the Co-PI with opportunities to foster collaborations both nationally and internationally. Fieldwork activities for this project resulted in 350 lots of newly collected crab specimens being deposited at the Florida Museum of Natural History (FLMNH). This also included curation of live images from over 300 specimens and genetic tissue samples from over 250 specimens. These specimens, tissue samples, and photographs are made freely available for future research through FLMNH. This project also included the digitization of over 1000 crab specimens from the FLMNH and Smithsonian National Museum of Natural History (USNM). These photographs were captured such that they are suitable for geometric morphometric work and will be made freely available through the respective institution’s online databases or the iDigBio portal (https://www.idigbio.org/portal/). This project facilitated the training of a female undergraduate student on research methods in molecular systematics that led to her successful completion of an undergraduate honors thesis. Finally, preliminary results of this work were communicated to over 450 members of the public. Through five outreach events at the USNM and the FLMNH over 400 members of the general public and 30 high school students were provided clear examples and hands on activities demonstrating how collections based research is conducted, why museums are critical for such research, and why everyone should care about developing a deeper understanding about biodiversity. All of this was framed within the context of the research conducted for this grant and in the process participants left with a greater appreciation for the biology and diversity of an economically and ecologically important group of crustaceans.


Last Modified: 09/02/2016
Modified by: Nathaniel M Evans

Diversification of these crabs included significant ecological divergence that involved abandoning a swimming lifestyle for sedentary, symbiotic relationships with reef-associated organisms (soft coral, algae, echinoderms, etc.). Results of this work contribute to an active area of research concerned with how external (e.g. ecological) and internal (e.g. developmental) factors influence morphological diversification. This project resulted in the development of significant molecular and morphological data for investigating this topic. The project provided the Co-PI with opportunities to foster collaborations both nationally and internationally. Fieldwork activities for this project resulted in 350 lots of newly collected crab specimens being deposited at the Florida Museum of Natural History (FLMNH). These specimens, tissue samples, and photographs are made freely available for future research through FLMNH. This project also included the digitization of over 1000 crab specimens from the FLMNH and Smithsonian National Museum of Natural History (USNM). This project facilitated the training of a female undergraduate student on research methods in molecular systematics that led to her successful completion of an undergraduate honors thesis. Finally, preliminary results of this work were communicated to over 450 members of the public. Through five outreach events at the USNM and the FLMNH over 400 members of the general public and 30 high school students were provided clear examples and hands on activities demonstrating how collections based research is conducted, why museums are critical for such research, and why everyone should care about developing a deeper understanding about biodiversity. All of this was framed within the context of the research conducted for this grant and in the process participants left with a greater appreciation for the biology and diversity of an economically and ecologically important group of crustaceans.
